newsitem.title: USA: Outflows from Fidelity Magellan slowed in March.
newsitem.headline: Outflows from Fidelity Magellan slowed in March.

text.p: Flows out of Fidelity Investments' Magellan Fund appeared to slow in March to less than $550 million, its lowest amount since June last year, analysts said.
Investors cashed out a net $521 million in March, down from $623 million in February, $1.2 billion in January, said David O'Leary, president of Alpha Equity Research.

The $51.4 billion fund, the largest in the country, has had outflows every month since April last year, he said, due to its poor performance versus the S&P500 and most other broad indices of the U.S. stock market.
Eric Kobren, the publisher of Fidelity Insight, estimated that outflows from Magellan in March totalled $540 million, down from $630 million in February.
"I think it's going to continue to get better, from Fidelity's perspective," Kobren said. "It will get better as people focus less on last year's performance and more on this year's performance."

Since the beginning of the year, Magellan has lost 0.56 pct, versus a loss of 1.78 percent for the average growth fund, while the S&P500 has climbed 7.08 percent, according to Morningstar Mutual Funds.
O'Leary estimated that Fidelity's U.S. stock funds had a net cash inflow of $1.6 billion in March, about nine percent of an estimated total inflow of $17.5 billion inflow for the industry, he said.
Among other Fidelity funds, Equity-Income had a net outflow of $477 million, Growth & Income lost a net $423 million and Disciplined Equity lost $279 milllion, he said.
